about.bio: Rishi Mirchandani is an Indian-American pianist based in New York City. At 18, he made his major orchestral debut with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, having accumulated six first-prize awards in national and international piano competitions. He made his first of three appearances at Weill Recital Hall of Carnegie Hall at the age of 12. Outside New York, Mirchandani has performed at Heinz Hall in Pittsburgh, the Aronoff Center in Cincinnati, Centro Cultural de Belém in Portugal, Real Collegio di Lucca in Italy, and more. His 2014 recording of Nancy Galbraith's Three Preludes for Piano was featured on the acclaimed Centaur Records album Strange Travels, which garnered a spot on Fanfare Magazine's "Want List". Mirchandani has performed in masterclasses for a number of renowned pianists, among them Richard Goode, Boris Berman, Lang Lang, Eldar Nebolsin, and Ian Jones. Mirchandani is a native of Pittsburgh, where he studied with Luz Manríquez. He holds a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Yale University, from which he graduated summa cum laude in 2019. He earned Distinction in Mathematics and was one of twelve students from his class (top 1%) elected to Phi Beta Kappa as a junior. While pursuing his mathematics studies, he also studied piano with Elizabeth Parisot and founded the Yale Undergraduate Piano Collective. At commencement, he received the Stanton Wheeler and Marcia Chambers Award for outstanding artistic contributions to campus life. Mirchandani is now pursuing a master's degree in piano performance at the Manhattan School of Music as a winner of the President's Award scholarship. He is a former student of Solomon Mikowsky and currently studies with Jeffrey Cohen.
